William Shakespeare, son of a well-to-do glovemaker from Stratford-upon-Avon, Warwickshire, was an actor during the reigns of Elizabeth I and James VI/I. For most of his career, he worked with an acting troupe called The Lord Chamberlain’s Men, Lord Hunsdon’s Men (when the old Lord Chamberlain died and his son inherited the troupe), The Lord Chamberlain’s Men again (when the son was appointed to his father’s old job), and, finally, The King’s Men, when King James took them over. Shakespeare became a Sharer (partner) with a guaranteed share of the proceeds, which made him quite wealthy for a member of the middle class. (The connection with nobles and the King was that, legally, actors counted as beggars, without the excuse of being crippled. For all practical purposes, it was a crime to be an actor. But if someone of the upper classes wished his servants to do plays for him, that was perfectly OK, and those servants obviously needed to rehearse, and if they rehearsed in a theater building, and charged the public money to come in and see, well, if their lord didn’t mind, that was OK, too.) Shakespeare started writing plays. And he turned out to be quite good at it. Nearly all his plays were hits, and after a while, they even started being sold in book form, though usually either stolen or after they’d gone out of fashion, since it was to the company’s advantage to keep a monopoly on them. He wrote comedies, tragedies, history plays about England, and, starting around the time his granddaughter was born, strange plays that are almost fairy tales; nowadays we call those the romances. He also wrote some straight poems, but the only way way you could make much money off poetry was to include a dedication to a rich person and say you couldn’t have done it without them, etc., and hope you’d be thrown a big bag of money. Plays where you got a percentage of the gross were a better deal. Over the years, of course, his plays came to be seen as old-fashioned. He wrote a few more in partnership, but soon retired to Stratford-upon-Avon, and, after a few years, he died. A generation afterwards, under the dictatorship of Oliver Cromwell, acting was made thoroughly illegal. But that lasted only a little while, and theatre came back. The plays from Shakespeare’s later days came back, and there were new plays, too, but Shakespeare was not forgotten, and, in time, people began to see again that he was something really special. He understood people in a way that few writers ever have, and could see all the lies we tell ourselves, too. And he was a master of writing dialog in exquisite verse that nevertheless sounds just as though the character is making it up as he goes along. And he’s always mainly interested in telling a story, not in trying to impress us with some political or religious “message”. His only message is, “Look! Look at this! Isn’t it strange? Isn’t it funny? Isn’t it heartbreaking? Isn’t it beautiful?” There’s never been anyone else like him.
